text: our nice little catchphrases that we
have we should just put them all in the
dumpster the the most notable one is uh
don't reinvent the wheel um I think that
is uh an egregious piece of advice for
people and on a surface level right like
we constantly reinvent Wheels right
we've been doing that for since we
invented the early Wheels right like
wheels on chariots and ancient Rome look
nothing like wheels on F1 cars right so
we've reinvented the wheel over and over
and over and over again and we've
constantly improved it but I I don't
like that phrase specifically because
it's so anti- Innovation it's like oh
well the things we've already created
that's not where we're going to innovate
it's on the things that don't exist yet
but there's essentially nothing that
doesn't exist yet for most purposes it's
like you're not going to invent the next
internet or the next telephone or the
next television like truly like this is
a new thing you're going to improve
something that already exists so I think
when people are like you know just claim
like don't reinvent the wheel they're
kind of missing out on you know
opportunities to create newer and better
things and also I think like kind of the
counterargument to that might be like
okay well that's really about focusing
on what your main thing is especially
like for a startup or a company but to
that I would say like most companies
that exist in the longterm pivot away
from whatever their initial main idea
was like a great example of this is that
American Express started off as a
package company right they were like
Federal Express like FedEx or they were
like UPS they were shipping things and
then they sprung off into uh finance and
now they are one of the world's largest
finance companies and one of the major
credit card companies in the world um so
I think it's like to think that you
should only focus on like whatever your
main thing is right now and not pay
attention to the things around you that
you might be able to innovate and change
on is also bad advice for people
um so I think we should kind of dispense
with quips like that and stop saying
like don't reinvent the wheel and
actually find more nuanced words for
what we're trying to explain to people
whether that's hey that might be a good
idea but we don't have the bandwidth to
focus on that right now or hey that
sounds like a good idea but you need to
develop it out more before we can
actually go and pursue it or or whatever
the thing is that you're trying to
explain to the person as to why they
shouldn't be doing it I think just the
little quips of don't reinvent the wheel
or even the the even more popular ones
like don't repeat yourself uh they they
mean so much at this point that they
mean basically nothing and they are I
think actively hostile and holding us

back
